Music Production

Escape

D'Dario

This song is made with a combination of MIDI and live instrument. The drums were created using Logic's Drummer plugin which was then altered to better fit the dynamics of the song and the flow of lyrics. The bass is also MIDI, using u plugin called MODO Bass which helped me get a more live feel. The guitars were recorded directly to logic and then amped in the box.

For the vocals, I used a mixture of microphones depending on a vocal part to get a bigger depth of sounds in the mix. For the lead vocal, I used an RØDE NT2-A with a cardioid polar pattern, for the backing vocals and some of the harmonies I decided to go with a lower quality microphone to simulate the girth from older rock recording. To achieve that I used a Behringer C1 and the t.bone SC 400.

After all of the recordings were cleaned up using iZotope's RX 7 and the Vocals were then edited using Flex Pitch. In the mixing stage, some of the technics used were parallel compression for the lead vocals and the guitar solo, some side-chain compression on the kick and bass, etc.

Finally, I mastered the track to a LUFS level of -10dB.

Microphones used:

  • RØDE NT2-A
  • Behringer C1
  • the t.bone SC 400

Software:

  • Logic Pro X
  • iZotope's RX 7

Nonstock plugins:

  • MODO Bass
  • iZotope's Vocal Synth

Artwork:

  • Newcastlebeach
  • BSGStudio

Snaga

Đumi

For this song, all of the vocals and acoustic guitars were recorded with the Behringer C1 condenser microphone and the electric guitars through a DI, amping them in the box. Everything was recorded at about -18dB to make sure there was no clipping and for easier mixing later.

Once recorded I went through all of the vocals and manually gained down all of the sibilants. When it was time to start mixing, I bounced down all of the MIDI to audio (separating the drumkit into different tracks so that each piece of kit can be processed on its own) and did a demo mix with no effects, just volume and panning, to get a rough structure of where everything will sit in the mix.

Finally, the song was mastered with the LUFS at about -12dB. This was done by first removing all of the frequencies below 25Hz and above 18kHz, then going through an RMS compressor (slow attack and release, gain reduction of -3dB), then a multipressor to boost the low and high frequencies about 2db and reducing the mid-range by about -2dB to get a more balanced mix. Ending with logic’s limiter set at a ceiling of -0.1dB and bringing the gain up until the LUFS was at the desired level. 

Microphones used:

  • Behringer C1

Software:

  • Logic Pro X
  • iZotope's RX 7

Nonstock plugins:

  • MODO Bass
  • iZotope's Vocal Synth

Romantic Drama

D'Dario

This is my Thomas Newman inspired Romantic Drama piece. The intention was to create a composition suitable for a film of the mentioned genre in Newmans' style while still being original and not just copying note for note.

Heavily referencing Newman’s work on the “Cinderella Man”, “Tolkien” and “Passengers” I started by recreating Newman’s iconic piano sound and improvising short melodies on top of chords. Using “weird” sounding instrument to get the space and the uplifting sound for romance. I also noticed that in his scores he repeats the same short idea multiple times, every time expanding the sound and making it more complex. Every time this is done the complex chord would resolve and bring us into the next part of the score. Furthermore, there is extensive use of automation to recreate the instrumentation movement is his pieces, where strings and winds are coming in and out, constantly moving and evolving.

The piece is played entirely with MIDI using different sample libraries such as Spitfire Labs and Symphony Orchestra, Epic Percussion and more.

Celebrations

D'Dario

Creating my take on the Celebrations Christmas advert I started by examining the video, looking for different cues and moods I needed to hit and represent.

Breaking down the piece we can see that there are only a few frames where the feeling of Christmas needs to be established after which we are quickly thrown into the "action". Using a mission impossible type of score was the best way to get a sense of that. The suspense build and the music reflects that by getting faster and higher until we get a moment of relaxation followed immediately by a glissando showcasing the falling of the characters. This brings us back to the warm yet childlike ending where we hear the first "Christmas" theme one last time.

The piece is played entirely with MIDI using the EastWest Symphonic Orchestra and the Logic Pro sample libraries.

Vjerujem

Đumi

This song was written in two days with the recording, mixing and mastering adding up to a week and a half. This song started like many others with a guitar since it is fairly slow passed and simple in its structure I decided to create multiple guitar parts to give it more scale and width. For the electric guitar, I asked a friend to record it while I was away from home.

Also for the ending vocal takes, I really wanted a female voice so I got another friend to record herself singing the line on the phone. It was very noisy and not in the right tempo so I first used RX 7 to get rid of all the noise and artefacts and then stretched the audio to the right tempo.

To better conceal it in the mix I used Vocal Synth to provide multiple harmonies, in the end, it created a vocoder effect that worked nicely as a backing in the song.

Finally, the song was mastered with the LUFS at about -14dB.

Microphones used:

  • Behringer C1
  • Android Phone

Software:

  • Logic Pro X
  • iZotope's RX 7

Nonstock plugins:

  • iZotope's Vocal Synth

Moj Bog, moj Otac

Zbor Piscatores

This song won the chance to be performed on national television with a live audience of about 2000 people.

Link to the performance here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7WuqfTN2q1M

I wrote the majority of this song at the age of 15 and then charged a couple of lines and add the bridge 3 years later. The music was written at the same time which I then further developed once finished with all of the lyrics. When arranging I wanted the song to always build and evolve with the lyrics which is why the chorus is never the same melodically. It is familiar to the listener but each time a bit different in the way it is sung.
